Review title: Trashy Flash - but rather charming nonetheless
Review_body: There is no denying that this movie is quite bad in many respects. Some of the actors are not very good, the whole plot is laughable, the characters are predictable and naive, and the whole style is way too glittery and Italian for this to have any taste at all.But strangely enough, this also works in its favour. The whole thing feels like a naive and glittery pulp cartoon from the 30ies, glamorous, adventurous, and often with little substance - and therefore quite fitting in its own way, regarding that Flash Gordon actually WAS all this.Still, the whole movie would still not be half as entertaining without the wonderful Queen score. Flashy, shallow, naive, glamorous and hero-worshiping - I bet those guys enjoyed themselves immensely with this!

Typical of an early eighties movie, this film is a classic feel-good fantasy movie. Flash Gordon is a physically fit and handsome man with absolutely no military experience, yet somehow proficient with all kinds of both human and alien weaponry AND is insanely hard to kill. He is the hero of this movie and is a footballer who finds himself the unwilling captor of Dr. Zarkov. Earth has fallen foul to some rather unusual atmospheric anomalies, which is actually the work or Ming the Merciless, ruler of Planet Mongo, who is testing Earth to see if it may compromise his rule. He comes to the conclusion that it will, and plans to destroy it. No one on earth is aware of what lies ahead, and are becoming increasingly scared due to the fact that the eccentric scientist Dr. Zarkov, formally of NASA, is the only one who has provided any explanation, and naturally, everybody thinks he is mad, because he talks of aliens and warring planets. So he travels to Mongo on his experimental rocket, and Flash and Dale Arden (the heroine of the movie) end up on board due to an unfortunate chain of events. The people on earth are unaware that their hero, a human named Flash armed only with a human's courage and his unique ability to dodge death, is fighting valiantly for their survival, while single-handedly negotiating a peace treaty between the warring factions of Mongo, as well as searching for his captured love Dale.It really is such a feel good film, with a great theme tune from Queen, in which you really do wish you were there fighting along side him as he courageously fights for the very survival of the human race. Naturally it isn't long before his name has spread throughout the planet of Mongo, and his enemies tremble at the very mention of his name, as they have never met a creature who is so courageous as the inhabitants of earth are (laugh, but in this film it is true).This film is definitely worth watching at least once for the fact that it is so fun, if nothing else. The acting isn't bad, nor are the special effects by any stretch. Watch this film and you won't regret it.
A gloriously bonkers pantomime with a very cool theme tune by Queen.

Review title: If you think its bad you're missing the point
Review_body: I loved this movie when i was about seven, and I enjoy it even more on the same childish level today.  This is a movie that doesnt ask you to suspend belief or insult your intelligence, because it is so blatantly make believe right up front. I truly believe that the makers of this movie set out to make an over the top hammy piece of cinema. I dont think anyone can argue that, in that respect, they succeeded.  I admit that Sam J. Jones is a terrible actor (even dubbed) but it lends it self nicely to the fact that flash just isnt that bright.  And whether intentional or not, the bad acting in this film just helps it pull off the cheesiness to perfection.  No movie with lines such as "I love you! But we only have fourteen hours left to save the earth!" could be considered a serious dramatic entity.  Frankly I find the approach that this movie takes to be refreshing, especialy when compared with some ridiculously plotted movies, that while good in their own right, insult our inteligence by taking themselves seriously (Lord of the Rings, Star Wars, etc). My advise to anyone watching this movie is to not expect Gone With the Wind or Casablanca.  Just have fun! And dont hold the absurdity and cheesiness of this movie against it, because its intentional, and done beautifuly!

Ordinarily, I'm only ever moved to review movies that I see have an unwarranted amount of very low ratings that are simply undeserved. However, in this instance, the opposite is true. I remember watching this movie in 1981, when I was 9, and thinking it was really bad. It came out in 1980, the same year as the Empire Strikes Back and in comparison its special effects are abysmal. As is the script, the design, and the acting. Since then the movie has gained something of a cult following, and there are a substantial number of reviewers that argue the hammy vibe of this movie is deliberate and that "if you think it's bad then you don't get it". This is just nonsense. Its bad because it's badly made. The script is rubbish, and they changed it as they shot. Director Mike Hodges claims that at the time it was the only "improvised $20 million movie". Some claim its its so bad it's good, or rate it highly due to some sort of nostalgic fondness. Unfortunately, to me, it's a desperate mess that not even Queen's fabulous music can save.

Review title: Best Sci-Fi Camp Rock Opera Ever Made!!! Fun-Campy-SciFi!!
Review_body: Hands down this is the BEST Sci-Fi /Campy movie ever made. The rock music from Queen is awesome as is the colorful cinematography. There are great actors and great direction from director Mike Hodges who bring camp to the sci-fi genre. This film was produced by the late legendary producer Dino De Laurentiis who sadly passed away in 2010. I saw this movie decades ago and again on the new Blue-Ray 2010 DVD and it is the sharpest format version of the movie I have ever seen, I highly recommend the HD Blue-Ray DVD. Great interviews from the original screen writer and Alex Ross comic artist as well as the original first 1930's episode Flash Gordon serial in the DVD extras section.This movie was made to be CAMPY. If you enjoy campy films like the Rocky Horror Picture Show that never takes itself seriously with great rock music, fun lines, then this movie is for you. It was never meant to be a "serious sci-fi" film. If you want a serious sci-fi film go watch Avatar, Blade Runner or 2001. Breck Eisner is reported to be working on a 2013 version of Flash Gordon that is supposed to be a "non-campy" version so there is that film too if you are looking for serious sci-fi version of Flash Gordon.This film is adapted and stays true to the original Flash Gordon comic book serial of the 1930's. IMO the legendary actor, Max Von Sydow was the best actor in this 1980 Flash Gordon movie and the best actor to ever play Ming the Merciless!! Compare Sydow's acting performance to the actor Charles Middelton in the 1930's Flash Gordon serials and they are not even in the same universe (no pun intended)!! Not only does he play the character perfectly but his intro in the beginning is classic camp, as Ming decides to toy with Earth's destruction in the cross hairs with Queen rock music in the background!! Too many great scenes to mention!! There are a a ton of other who's who British "thespian" actors that do a fabulous job in the film. Just sit back enjoy the rock music and all the campy fun!!

When this movie came out in 1980 it was not well received. Here - about 40 years later - it is an absolute gem. It is definitely the best of bad movies and it just has this magical vibe that cannot be explained. Some people hate it but I would not be without it.

Review title: You'd understand if you were 5 when you first saw this
Review_body: note: this is written by Liz's Husband I went to the cinema when I was 5 years old to see this and it was the most exciting and spellbinding thing I'd ever seen.Its unique soundtrack and set design made this an instant classic and obviously at that age notions of the film being camp were completely non existent yet I did get princess Aura (possibly my first crush) and was terrified by the monster in the swamps of Auboria and remember being unable to watch the whole sequence.Flash was a role model for me and and when they started showing Buster Crabb on morning TV during the summer holidays I was hooked. The only fault I have with Flash Gordon is that they never made the sequel, oh and there was no Lion Men in it, but maybe they were saving them for the sequel, that would of been cool.Even now 25 years later this is still one of my favourite films, it just cant be topped. Its stays true to the comic and TV series and lets face it just about everything in Star Wars is taken from the Flash Gordon saga, even though you cant compare the two. You cant take Flash seriously and come on your not supposed to - if they had made it all serious and dark it would of been terrible, instead they made something tongue-in-cheek that is exciting and funny and for all the family.So the point I really want to make is that to a 5 year old the film was never camp - it was funny exciting and scary with even a dash of romance "I love you flash, but we've only got 14 hours to save the earth" I mean come on that line itself is funny, romantic, exciting and scary all rolled into one!!! LOL

This is a sci-fi family blockbuster directed by the chap who gave us the gritty '70s gangster movie Get Carter. Its two leads can't act at all and are barely engaging. The performances are completely uneven to the extent that actors seem to think they're in different films to each other: from plank-like (Sam Jones, Melody Anderson) to straight-faced and serious (Timothy Dalton), to so louche he should have a cocktail in his hand in every scene (Peter Wyndgarde) to barely directed and simply having fun (Brian Blessed) to jokey and slightly hammy (Topol), to pure ham (Mariangela Melato). After Star Wars and Alien had set a benchmark for sci-fi being a bit dark and grimy its like they threw all that out and decided that sci-fi should look polished, shiny and colourful. And the soundtrack is by Queen, with the preposterousness and pomp turned up to eleven.And yet it works, and it works stupendously well. Whilst this isn't my favourite film there are very, very few I enjoy quite as much as Flash Gordon. After a very dull first ten or so minutes involving the aforementioned unengaging leads taking a plane journey we meet Topol's Dr Hans Zarkov and the pace, and sense of fun, never lets up until the end. Its extraordinary stuff with so many memorable set-pieces: Ming's first on-screen appearance to Queen's menacing synth music, Flash's ludicrous game of "American Football" in Ming's throne room, the tree- stump monster, the whip battle on the tilting platform (with retracting spikes, naturally), the hawkmen attacking a rocketship. And so many brilliant, fun lines: "Flash, flash I love you but we only have fourteen hours to save the earth!", "Dispatch war rocket Ajax to brrring back his body!", "Gordon's alive?!!"Incredibly for a film with two such poor lead performances everyone else is brilliant. Topol is on great form as Zarkov bringing the charisma that worked so well in the Bond film For Your Eyes Only, Dalton plays the whole thing utterly straight as chiseled Prince Barrin, Blessed is essentially just playing himself but it would be half the film without him, Peter Wyngarde manages to give Klytus an air of upper-class menace from behind a metal mask and Max von Sydow portrays Emperor Ming so well that he manages to make an essentially 2D B-movie type villain into someone who comes across as complex and interesting.I hesitate to use phrases like "popcorn movie" or "leave your brain at the door" about Flash Gordon because that's doing it a massive injustice. This is a brilliant, funny, clever, outrageously camp and even slightly subversive film hiding in the most commercial of genres. We will never see its likes again and that's a shame.

I think most people who have seen this movie released it was a joke. I don't know if they meant it to be this way, but for me this movie looks like been done bad on purpose. And in this case, it works. The plot is thin, but extremely classic. Ming is fantastic fun to watch. Flash is over played, Yale is fall after 10 min in love with Flash, Dr Zar...Zargto... the smart guy is lovely crazy.If you don't get humor in this movie after 20 min, turn it off. But if you do get it, you gonna love it. This movie is made in the 80's, but made as it was in the 30's. If you are a sci fi fan, I say pick it up. I'm sure you gonna find it amusing.

I loved this film as a kid when it first came out. I must have watched it a hundred times when we got a VHS video recorder, and I was already well into Queen (the first band I ever 'got into') so I knew the soundtrack off by heart. The last time I saw the film was probably a couple of years after it came out.Now it can be very unwise to revisit things you loved as a little kid, as I'm sure many of you have found out for yourselves, because they're never anywhere near as good as you remember, very often you realise they're the worst sort of garbage you could imagine, and this can be a very upsetting, traumatic experience; heartbreaking even. A few years ago I found myself watching an old episode of the original Battlestar Galactica, the late '70s one, (not the pretty decent '00s one with Katee Sackhoff and Edward James Olmos) and it was truly abysmal - just the worst - and I used to LOVE it! But the worst thing is that I never seem to learn my lesson and just stop watching things again, so I can stop destroying little parts of my childhood.And guess what? I've gone and done it again and rewatched Flash Gordon... and it was absolutely amazing!! One of the best things I've seen in ages - even better than it was when I was a kid!! Oh sure, it was so cheesy, and as camp as could be, with terrible special effects, but what I hadn't picked up on as a kid is that it was funny as hell - and I don't mean so bad it's good sort of funny either. The damn thing's a comedy! I rarely laugh out loud when I watch things on my own, but when Timothy Dalton came skidding into the control room yelling "Freeze, yuh bluddy basturds!" in the strangest, broadest North English accent (I daren't say Yorkshire!), well, I was just p¡ssing myself. Something else I hadn't picked up on, perhaps not surprisingly, was how kinky (and borderline dodgy!) the whole affair is, and Ornella Muti is just so damn sexy as Princess Aura. The sorely missed Max Von Sydow is having a whale of a time as Ming The Merciless yet still somehow manages to bring an air of gravitas to something this camp 'n kitsch. Astonishing!So if you loved this back in the '80s and were a kid back then but haven't seen it since, go give it a look see - otherwise it might be best to steer clear...Bring me... the bore worms!No! Not the bore worms!

Review title: Knowingly Camp version of matinée sci-fi classic
Review_body: During the middle section of this movie, our hero 'Flash' Gordon, accompanied by Ornella "Most beautiful woman in the world" Muti, witnesses ex Bond Timothy Dalton giving ex Blue Peter presenter Peter Duncan the sweet merciful release of death by putting him to the(cardboard) sword (offscreen). "Its an initiation" purrs the shapely Muti, "I just love initiations".This 1980 version of the perennial Saturday morning sci-fi cliffhanger is a feast for the senses. That is, if your senses crave lashings of junkfood. With an eye meltingly lurid palette of colours and rocktastic Queen soundtrack Flash Gordon was the perfectly overblown movie for the start of an overblown decade. The costumes are extravagantly cheesy, the effects farcical, the acting hilarious. Almost every minor character was hammed up to perfection by the cream (or perhaps custard) of character actors of the time including such luminaries as Rocky Horrors Richard O Brien, Phillip "I corrected them" Stone from the Shining and the half-man, half-beast that is Brian Blessed. The only minor flaw in this popcorn delight is the fact that it is, in almost every way - a terrible, awful movie - I HIGHLY recommend it.

I first saw this movie at the cinema aged ten, my late father took me to see it because my favourite band did the music, I loved every second of it, later that week my big sister took me to see it a further 2 times. These are some of my best memories. I'm now typing this aged 50 enjoying it all over again and actually reciting it word for word. A must see for everyone young and old

Review title: This movie is so ugly, it hurts
Review_body:
The art direction and costumes are so ugly, it hurts to watch this movie. Even if one would try to make a Chinese restaurant look ugly, one wouldn't be able to come up with a decor as ugly as seen throughout this film.
The acting and script are no better, so it is camp after all.1 out of 10!

I love this film. It's one of the first movies I've ever seen. I'm also impressed incredibly by the fact that Queen, a rock band did the musical scoring to this entire film. Not only that, but the sets, costumes are colorful, as is the acting, despite the ignorant remarks about the acting ability of Sam J. Jones as Flash Gordon himself. It's also very exciting near the end with the hawkmen and Flash battling the Rocket Ajax and Flash crash landing it into mingo city. It's a joy ride you'll never forget!

Review title: Fish in a Barrel for MST3King...
Review_body: If you enjoy sitting around watching a movie with friends and doing the Mystery Science Theater 3000 thing, this movie is perfect.  It's pure drivel with a big enough budget that it should have been good, which makes it all the more fun.  From Flash's array of conveniently labeled shirts (all either say "Flash" or bear an appropriate emblem) to Dale Arden's bizarre performance, this one's a keeper.  >And if you're wondering why the hero is such a dunce, remember what Queen points out in the theme song - "He's just a man / Who can never fail" - the gods figured once they'd imbued this guy with that kind of power, why waste intelligence, coordination, or acting skills?  Go Flash go...

Review title: This Ming is a Psycho! Who said that ?
Review_body: This is without a doubt one of the greatest sci-fi adventures to ever grace the silver screen and I make that statement without the slightest hint of sarcasm. The opening credits pretty much sum it up, this is a 30's comic book slicked up with an 80's soundtrack and it delivers just that. Sam Jones performance was just right I  don't know if it was intentional but it works as does Melody Anderson's. Topol is always good as is Brian Blessed and Max Von Sydow. Timothy Dalton was magnificent as Barin and... I could go on and on about the performances. The soundtrack was freakin awesome. Some people remark on the cheesiness of the special effects and sets but that was the whole point! This is literaly a comic book played by live actors. Anyway, great movie!

Review title: So much effort for so little...
Review_body: The production of this film took, believe it or not, a lot of time to complete.  The costumes alone were enough to watch this movie for. Unfortunately, the U.S. market didn't see it the same way.  But I love this movie because they tried so hard.  The lines of Melody Anderson as Dale Arden were mostly very out of place, and sometimes irritating, but the movie is well worth watching.

Review title: Highest honors to all on set for their commitment to the project.
Review_body: Costumes are magnificent. New and bizarre people and places are thrust upon us, with every detail imaginable. Believe for a second that you're a small boy and watching these likable characters go through with saving the earth. Yes, there is some cringed dialogue. But man oh man, these actors have given it their all and I applaud each and every one who helped make this fever dream.At any point I was ready for a muppet to be a character, but it never happened.

It's hard to review Flash Gordon without saying "trashy", "camp" or "tounge in cheek" but they sum up the film perfectly. What comes across when watching is the love that went into it: the amazing design, sets, spaceships and of course costumes. The vivid colours and skies are stunning. OK, the special effects may not be photo realistic or even half convincing, but they suit the film and add to the comic book feel. The cast is also fantastic, people knock Sam jones but again, his (famously dubbed) performance seems to suit the film. Max von Sydow has great fun with Ming, while Brian Blessed as Vultan steals the film. And Ornella Muti is just the sexiest woman alive. Finally mention must go to both Queen and Howard Blake for the score, again just brilliant. See this movie!

When I first started to watch this movie I was like !@#$ this is going to be bad, considering the budget for this movie is drained from all the special effects they use to make this movie but when it actually got into the story, however a little annoyance in my mind was complaining how bad and idiotic the plot was but I ignored it and continued to laugh my !@#$ing ass off.This movie is so !@#$ing crazy and messed up that you think the director was on drugs making this movie. After watching the movie, I started to do research and found out it was based on an old comic book way back. Which brings me to another point.Now was it me or was the main Villain's assistant the step brother of Dr. Doom cause seriously, he looks just like him. The main Villain also look like Iron Man arch foe with all the rings and !@#$ and that Chinese look.But really as crazy and as stupid the movie is, you will be entertained by the movie and how crazy and how stupid it really is.It also contains the best quote in a movie I've ever heard."Flash, I love you but we only have 14 hours to save the Earth!"

I have just watched the movie for the first (2014), and not the last time, and I *think* I really enjoyed it. Let me try to explain.There were moments when it seemed like the movie was trying to impress and wrap you up in its other-worldliness, and they often worked well, like the green jungle/swamp scenes. Then it would suddenly switch to really duff scenes, e.g. the hawkmen flying en masse, and not one of the little black things seemed to move, resulting in a swarm of cigarette ash over the top right part of the screen. The flying scenes, spaceships and all, were cringeworthy. But then you laugh, because it's meant to be an animated (with humans) comic.Thing is, I would be getting into the comic atmosphere, then it would get more movie-like, and I wasn't sure if I should laugh or die. The script was funny (the clichés) and sometimes hilarious (the total lack of respect for life), but it often fell flat and made me go yuckkk when it was too predictable, and that's not good comedy. Nor is it serious. Just iffy.Overall, I enjoyed it, and I will be watching it again with a couple of friends, when we can point things out and laugh or just comment. However, I cannot imagine for the life of me why anyone would fancy the heroine with the fat face. Dog-like, as in a boxer. Still, good movie!

If you decide to watch Flash Gordon, don't be alarmed by the bad grade it gets on IMDB. You just approach it as the early eighties flick it is. If you look at the cheesy costumes, the bad special effect and the hilarious one-liners and laugh at them, then you'll love it. If you can't laugh about that, then you'll hate it.My love for the movie is mainly based on one thing: the soundtrack. All the music in the movie is composed and performed by Queen. The music of the most famous glamrock band in history makes it worth while. If you love Queen, you must watch this movie, there's no doubt about that.Main conclusion, you'll love it or you'll hate it. If you're looking for a Spiderman-like adaption of a comic book, don't watch this movie. If you like retro-style films that you'll mostly find in your small movie house in stead of your large 20-studio cinema and/or if you love Queen, like me then this is a must see movie.

With a great mix of good actors & zany characters this is a fun classic cult film!As a tween in the 80's I watched this film dozens of times - as 80's kids did with too much time & no internet...What I remember is a fun & exciting story of a NY QB who ends up saving the world from the evil Ming. Had enough creative use of characters, 80's technology, fights, romantic relations and good old good vs. evil to make it worth watching again and again...enJOY!

I have purchased as many DVDs and VHS copies as needed for my big family as Christmas gifts. It will thrill all members from 4-104, so I know I can't go wrong. Neither can you! Don't miss this vintage character, Flash Gordon, in his 1980 spectacular update! It is sort of tongue-in-cheek ,perhaps , but certainly captures the original strip's far out sci-fi feeling,and visual impact-- and beyond Too bad I missed it on the big screen, it must have been smashing, but you too, will be very satisfied with a home video version. Whatever your age this is totally cool!The story concept contains many twists and turns, and the variety of evil doers are truly eye-popping. I particularly loved the "non-sophisticacation" of the film. I appreciated an absence of "Hollywood over-kill special effects". They managed to pull this film off with minimal bombing and ear-drum shattering sound effects! A must see!

Flash Gordon is an incredible film, the finest B movie ever made.  A pounding soundtrack from Queen drives you through unique alien landscapes and the co-stars of this film deliver stunning performances (Max von Sydow, Topo, Timothy Dalton, Ornella Muti and Brian Blessed).  The only reason why this is a B movie instead of celebrated as much as Star Wars is s weak showing from Sam J. Jones and Melody Anderson.  Nevertheless Flash Gordon is even more fun to watch today than it was 20 years ago when it was released.

Review title: at last the recognition it deserves
Review_body: having seen this movie over twenty years ago it's great that there are so many people that enjoyed it as much as i did. i found that the one dimensional characters were perfectly suited to appeal to the simplistic way i viewed life as a twelve year old boy. the heroic nature displayed by flash and the prince etc helped to reinforce a measure of chivalry in my young brain. i feel that this film is the most impressive adaptation of a comic strip that i have ever witnessed. who needs heros that have psychological damage? is that not the reason that we escape reality? the sound track was awesome and the music from the "dive" scene still give gives me goose bumps today. i recommend this film to anybody that is mature enough to laugh at themselves

Jones made for a perfect Flash.Perfect physique and innocent stance. Dalton's Shakespearian airs perfectly complemented Jone's Quarterback Dynamo. Blessed did what it says on the tin and I prefer Blessed's booming to arty farty acting. The Italian lady who played Aura was sizzling. Topol gave Zharkov a unique understated edge. Review title: What is not to like about this movie?
Review_body: Delightful, wonderful, sexy cheese. Gorgeous costumes, fantastic Queen soundtrack, glorious comic book-style cinematography.This is such a fun movie to watch; I liked it the first time I saw it back in 1980, and I still like it 25 years later.The dialogue is exceedingly silly, but that is part of the charm--hearing Max von Sydow sneering, "Pathetic Earthlings," or Brian Blessed, schlocking through lines like, "Onward my brave Hawkmen! Let this be known forever as Flash Gordon's Day!" Bahahahahaa! Excellent! And the soundtrack is done by QUEEN! Really, that would be enough to get me to watch this. And when you add in the lushly colored sets and ultra-fab costumes, this film is a gem.

Review title: Do not die before you have seen this film
Review_body: This film will change your life.  In the early 80's, audiences left cinemas in a state of shock, unable to cope with their daily lives having been exposed to the vision of this film.Taking the seemingly unpromising pulp 30's serials as its starting point this film weaves an elaborate web of plot, counter-plot, intrigue, deception and betrayal - most of this lost on the "average" viewer.  It is of course an example of cinema as Opera (in the true Wagnerian sense) with Queen's landmark soundtrack - notably making a sly nod to their influence with their rendering of his wedding march from Lohengrin.This film contains some of the most emotionally stripped-bare performances ever committed to film.  It is so rare that a director finds actors so devoted to his vision.  It is a genuine ensemble piece, with each element enhancing and complementing the others.

Review title: For pure, ridiculous fun, nothing beats Flash Gordon.
Review_body:
Klytus, I'm bored. What play thing can you offer me today?For pure, ridiculous fun, nothing beats Flash Gordon. It's sugar saturated sci-fi cheese. You couldn't survive on a diet of such fare, but it makes for a great treat after a season of, say, The Wire (which is so real and grim it's like beating your hopes with a two by four for an hour).Flash Gordon is right up there with delights like Army of Darkness and Galaxy Quest.Based on the comic strip by Alex Raymond (which was King Features Syndicate's answer to Buck Rogers), this movie doesn't just indulge in tropes, it rolls around in them like a pig in mud. It's like someone sent the writer's internal sophistication censor packing and let his inner ten year old run riot: this film has Hawkmen, an entire civilization of Robin Hood look-a-likes in green tights (honestly, is there only one clothes manufacturer in Arborea?), floating cities, ray guns, sword fights, rocket cycles, hideous monsters, beautiful maidens and seductive femme fatales.What's not to like?According to the director, Mike Hodges (who also directed Michael Crichton's The Terminal Man), it's "the only improvised $27 million dollar movie ever made."In one early scene, our eponymous hero actually identifies himself to the alien Emperor Ming as 'Quarterback, New York Jets' as if this would have meaning to an alien overlord. Then he plays 'irresistible force' linebacker to Ming's flat footed Imperial Goon Squad lineup, and starts tossing about a metal egg like it's a football, all while Dale Arden cheers him on from the sidelines.It's high octane kitsch and it's totally awesome.That's the miracle of Flash Gordon.European DNA suffuses the flick and there are few Americans in the cast. In particular, the over-the-top art direction (What isn't over-the-top about Flash Gordon?) is more reminiscent of Barbarella than Star Wars.And then there's the sociopolitical subtext. It's most obvious in the hero and the villains, who embody stereotypes from the mid-Twentieth Century.Flash Gordon (Sam Jones), the all American football quarterback hero, simply put, is America: bright eyed, naive, idealistic, just brimming over with hope and positivity. You want to pinch his cheeks. He's eager to stand up for what's right while being utterly oblivious to larger political ramifications. His exhortations to team up and fight Ming ("Ming is the enemy of every creature of Mongo! Let's all team up and fight him.") are dismissed as simple-minded to the jaded barons of Mongo. These lords cannot even conceive of playing a positive sum game, so broken is their sense of justice.The villains are Europeans: Max von Sydow (Ming), Timothy Dalton (Barin), Brian Blessed (Vultan), Peter Wyngarde (General Klytus), Mariangela Melato (Kala), and Ornella Muti (Aura). They're sophisticated, cynical, duplicitous, Machiavellian, and engaged in endless, internecine struggle. They'd stab their own mother in the back if it'd get them a cookie. Dominated by their tyrannical Emperor Ming, they believe one can only win if others lose.It's a planet of narcissistic manipulators, but they have sex appeal to make up for it.Sydow as Ming contrasts beautifully with Sam Jones' Flash: Sydow's Ming is a brilliant, charistmatic megalomaniacal, narcissistic psychopath.
Dale Arden (Melody Anderson) is the perfect female compliment to Flash, all earnest and well meaning American pie. She proves resourceful and spunky, as a New York gal should.
Thoroughly tongue in cheek, and all the better for it, Flash Gordon knows it's preposterous, a spiritual ancestor of Axe Cop, relentlessly fun and enjoyable.The screenwriter, Lorenzo Semple, Jr., wrote for the Sixties Batman TV show, and it shows. Batman and Flash share a similar, campy sensibility, although Flash is buoyed by a far bigger budget and has better action sequences with real tension.Semple himself didn't want to make it a comedy:"Dino wanted to make Flash Gordon humorous. At the time, I thought that was a possible way to go, but, in hindsight, I realize it was a terrible mistake. We kept fiddling around with the script, trying to decide whether to be funny or realistic. That was a catastrophic thing to do, with so much money involved... I never thought the character of Flash in the script was particularly good. But there was no pressure to make it any better. Dino had a vision of a comic-strip character treated in a comic style. That was silly, because Flash Gordon was never intended to be funny. The entire film got way out of control."And Dino only read Semple's scripts after they were translated into Italian:"He reads English better than many people realize, but translates all of his scripts into Italian. We were living in Nantucket at the time, and his translator was a woman whose name I forget. She could barely translate the scripts; if it said, 'The tall, beautiful woman walked into the room,' she'd say, 'Oh, what a beautiful cat.'"It just gets more absurd: on set, not only could many people not communicate on essential matters due to language barriers, not everyone was even on the same page regarding the tone of the film, at least according to Melody Anderson (Dale Arden):"The director said, 'I want you and Sam to try to go for a relationship, make this as human as possible. Don't camp it up or go for laughs.' That's why the movie's so funny, because we didn't try to make it campy. In fact, I'm surprised that (people) are laughing, because we weren't out to make a funny film. In fact, De Laurentiis was very upset when he showed the film and people started to laugh, because he thought they were laughing at it and not with it. In fact, he re-did the cheerleading scene. He wanted it to be serious...with macho man out there. Play it very straight, the more you play it straight, the funnier it is. I think that's why Flash and Dale work, because of the way we played it."Sometimes when you skirt the edge of The Abyss of Total and Utter Catastrophe you wind up escaping with something unexpectedly, accidentally wonderful.
There are great action sequences, and yet the goofiness is never allowed to undermine them or rob the film of (admittedly lighthearted) dramatic tension. It's a cartoon struggle for an alien world, but still a struggle, and not quite so wink-wink that you're thrown out of the adventure aspect entirely.Most of the characters get at least a few instantly classic lines:Princess Aura: But my father has never kept a vow in his life!
Dale Arden: I can't help that, Aura. Keeping our word is one of the things that make us better than you.Ming: It's what they call tears. It's a sign of their weakness.And then there's the kick-ass theme song. It was the first time a rock band scored a major picture (Queen'd follow it up with Highlander's score), and Queen threw themselves into the task with gusto. Dino had never heard of them before, but he was nothing if not willing to experiment. They came back with a soundtrack that makes you want to stand up and cheer, it's that feel good.Flash - a-ah - saviour of the universe

Review title: A real guilty pleasure of mine!
Review_body: "Flash Gordon" is a big budget science fiction fantasy that is completely enjoyable.  I saw this movie when I was 11 years old, and I remember coming out of the theater and telling my parents how great it was.  As an adult, I still find it a lot of fun.  The movie is intentionally very campy and unrealistic.  It is a homage to those 1930's serials that starred Buster Crabbe.  It's not in the same league as "Star Wars", but it was not intended to be.  "Flash Gordon" is less concerned with meticulous special effects and more concerned with characters in the story.  I personally  enjoyed that. Don't get me wrong though, there is plenty of action, colorful costumes, classic dialogue, and elaborate sets.  The movie is well paced with no lulls in the story.  Sam Jones as Flash is weak, but the rest of the cast is superb. There are two stand out performances.  Max Von Sydow is a formidable Ming the Merciless and Ornella Muti is perfect as the  alluring Princess Aura.  Overall, a real treat if you want some fun entertainment.

Sorry all you Flash Gordon's fans but this is a truly awful movie. I forced myself to see it all the way through and it was a pain. Loved it when I was 8 but now this is looks like a movie done by someone in a bad acid trip and by the time this movie was done, acid was already out of fashion. The music theme is good and inspiring but that is the only good thing I have to say about this title. The story is weak and the plot is basic and dull, the actors are awful never looking serious in their performance and the costumes are dreadful! Nothing in this movie looks even credible, we never believe the actors performance, and even the objects just look fake. Every rock we see, we now that it is made of Styrofoam and it sure looks like that. Absolutely no effort in making things look believable. Talking about direction well it is simply uninspired work. No sense in the story but not quit a nonsense movie so I don't see the point of it. It could had been a crazy, goofy movie, very artistic and wild as if it was out of a fairy tale like Alice in wonderland or City of Lost Children but it is simply a bad Hollywood movie perhaps a little bit out of its time.

Review title: The Sci Fi that reminds you of your childhood.
Review_body: Flash Gordon is one of those films that you either love or hate. It's camp direction can be taken a bit too seriously, however, Flash Gordon is still lovable and for me personally, it is a film that you can watch over and over again; smile at the typical good vs evil story and cringe at the roles of Timothy Dalton and Brian Blessed. But it's hard to knock Flash; with the music being composed by the UN-beatable Queen. (who hasn't sung FLASH!.........AAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHH!!!)Lets face it, Flash Gordon isn't the best Science Fiction around, or the best super-hero you can get, but Flash will always be a Cult treasure that will remind us of our childhood.

Review title: Queen rocks the kingdom of Mongo.
Review_body: I can't help but feel both nostalgic and elitist every time I throw on Flash Gordon.  In retrospect, my parents seemed to be the first people on the planet to own a Beta VCR, and I can remember watching a ragged copy of the film about a thousand times growing up.  My friend Jason and I would simulate the wood beast initiation scene daily, using one of those hideous old wooden coffee tables that my folks had.  You know, the ones that looked like a huge piece of driftwood?This movie has it all folks, campy or no.  Swirling psychedelic skies for all you children of the 60's.  A rockin' soundtrack by Queen.  Babes and hunks galore.  Battle, battle, and more battle.  The genius of Max  Von Sydow.  The genius of Topol.  And c'mon, you can't beat Brian Blessed, the man who brought us a very loud, very Shakespearean Hawk Man!The point is this: You don't have to have watched Flash Gordon 3 - 5 times a week for six years of your life to appreciate it.  Well ok, it probably wouldn't hurt...

Review title: The King of fun B movies
Review_body: I would never dream of arguing that this is a well made movie. This is a terribly made movie. But it is a fun movie, one that I can watch over and over again. For sheer loopy spectacle and giddy over-the-top performances, you can't beat it.

The acting is terrible and the dialogue is ridiculous, but this is what makes it absolutely brilliant.
I never get bored of this film. NEVER!
It never takes itself seriously, the music score is awesome, the costumes are great. It has Brian Blessed shouting a lot, James Bond in green tights, a guy from Blue Peter and Max Von Sydow hamming it up as the main villain.
Gonna watch it again now.

Review title: A Glorious Film of Earth Shattering Proportions
Review_body: This film is awesome on just about every level. It's camp, full of fabulously outrageous acting and is just downright silly. This is what film making ought to be about. Fun entertainment that doesn't take itself too seriously and with a soundtrack that will grab you by the throat and force you to have a good time.The fact that the special effects are a bit wobbly, the reconciliation between Flash and Barin is hilarious and the whole macho test of man-hood by Peter Duncan looks like a scene from Robin Hood meets Pricilla Queen of the Desert, are not weaknesses but just add to this film.Blake's 7 would not have been what it is if the sets hadn't of moved and Flash Gordon would never have worked without seventy miles of red and gold satin and lycra.Go Flash!

Review title: Brilliance personified as a movie. A marvel...
Review_body: A wonder...Dare I say, a masterpiece?...They don't make them like this beauty any more! Flash is the mad bomb. Dale is a hottie hot hot. Review_body: But also a lot of fun. This has to be one of the greatest film adaptations of a comic ever put to screen for the simple fact that it never takes itself too seriously. Hodges maintains a whimsical tone without succumbing to the "madcap" trap as did many of the 60's flicks in the same genre. Conversely, it doesn't attempt the utter absurdity of going for stark serious in a film about a football hero who saves the universe. Flash Gordon remembers that it's a live- action cartoon and takes it as far as it can go. Ornella Muti portrays one of the sexiest humans ever. The rest of the cast, pulled right out of the royal Shakespeare company, elevate the film to an recent classic. Plainly, this flick rocks. Go Flash, go!

This review does NOT contain spoilers. I will make references to certain characters but will not describe any particular situation or plot element.It boggles my mind when I see a movie review that complains about the campiness of a movie when the movie is supposed to be campy! Characterizations were perfect: The people of Earth are supposed to be from a place of relative normalcy while everything from Mongo is over-the-top. So Flash is confused and amazed, Dale is not as flashy as the Princess, and the professor is a mad scientist - but in a good way. Don't rag on their characters for this; celebrate it! They are all just as they should be and the actors did a fine job with their roles.Every time I played this movie, it was a hit. I wore out my VHS and need to get a DVD. But, the DVD is out of production and used copies are selling for about $100US at the time of this review. Obviously, a lot of people are voting with their wallet that this movie rates more than a 6!

The flick clearly lacks many qualities - but then, when I watch the first Star Wars movie today, I am shocked that I once liked that. But in the end it works all nicely. It is just perfect entertainment and the trashy elements don't affect the impact of the film in a negative way. I am sure this movie will soon be cult (maybe it already is). So all thumbs up for this great film!

Review title: Dun dun dun dun dun dun dun dun dun
Review_body: I know that the popular consensus has tagged this movie as campy and cheesy, but in the case of Flash Gordon, I don't think that's a bad thing at all. I was like 5 years old when I first saw this movie, so for me, it's not only a great film, it also brings me back to some of the happiest moments of my childhood when my imagination was limitless. Just listening to the soundtrack is enough to bring me back to my own personal "good ol' days," so I'll always have a soft spot for this movie in my heart. However, even viewing it as an adult, I have to say that I don't see quite as much cheese as the harsh critics see in the movie. I mean, yeah, there's that "cringe in your seat" moment when Melody Anderson side shuffles, claps her hands and cheers "Go, Flash, Go!" and her equally embarrassing, "Oh, Flash" when he saves Prince Baron from falling into the abyss, but beyond that, I think it's an awesome movie. I thought that all of the actors were very good in their respective roles, particularly Ming the Merciless, played by Max Von Sydow. He's very convincing in this role and not even remotely campy (IMHO). Klytus is also great. You gotta love his nonchalantly smooth manner of speaking. However, if I were to point out one thing that I believe made Flash Gordon the cult classic that it is today, it would HAVE to be the soundtrack. Right from the first scene when Ming starts pressing buttons that wreak havoc on the Earth, you hear the beat. Dun dun dun dun dun dun dun dun, then they hit you with that campy-as-hell "Flash! A-haaaaa!" before they break into song. The wedding march was exceptionally evil and just all of the music in between made the movie so memorable. Plus, the music helped freeze the movie permanently in 1980, which I love. If you've never seen this movie, DEFINITELY rent it and check it out. It's just a great flick.

The acting is so pathetic and the special effects are so hilarious that this is actually an entertaining. Do I even need to mention the costumes that everyone wears? This is absolutely ridiculous, but enjoyable.

I went to the theater when this movie first came out. This was a military theater and the crowd was primarily military trainees. The entire place was cheering the hero (Gordon) and booing the bad guy (Ming). The score by Queen is nothing short of fantastic, after all Freddie Mercury was one of a kind. If you want Academy Award performances then you'll want to pass on this one (except maybe Muti and the bore worms scene). But if you want a couple hours of plain fun and entertainment, then this movie is worth a look. One of my favorites. Sam Jones is more than passable as the "not to bright" jock and our hero. Melody Anderson has eyes to die for and Ornella Muti has far more than that. Max Von Sydow is superior as the tyrant Ming the Mercilous.

Though panned by all major critics it has become a cult classic.  It is a film ahead of it's time.  Special effects were above average for the time and there are plenty of hot chics to keep an eye on.  Though there is plenty of "Cheese" to go around in this film it is worth the time to watch it.

Dino DeLaurentiis' Flash Gordon is one of those rare movies that captures the imagination of the viewer, and doesn't let go until the final moments. It truly has everything you could ever want in a movie: compelling plot (the QB of the New York Jets has approximately 24 hours to save the Earth from total annihilation), violence, gore, great acting (Timothy Dalton, Brian Blessed, Max Von Sydow), action (the "Football Fight" in Ming's palace), drama, sexual situations (Princess Aura seducing Flash in her rocket, Dale Arden in Ming's bedroom), and babes (Ornella Muti as Princess Aura, and Melody Anderson as Dale Arden.)  What more can you ask for in a movie? Nothing, I tell you, NOTHING!!!  Actually, having read other comments elsewhere, I am extremely disappointed in the almost universal panning of the 2 leads, Sam J. Jones and Melody Anderson.  These two fine actors put forth a masterful performance, and made you really believe the situations their characters found themselves in.  I can't speak highly enough of their abilities, as they were never as good in anything else than they were here. Flash Gordon is the greatest movie of all-time- it has to be the greatest ever, because I wouldn't watch a movie over 300 timess if it wasn't.  You think I'm kidding, but I'm deadly serious.  The first time I saw it in the theater- 18 years ago- I was hooked for life.  Please, whatever you do, watch this movie over and over- you'll be glad you did.

Review title: Gloriously over the top acting.Very enjoyable.
Review_body: This film has received a lot of criticism over the years,however having watched this film twice in the last few days all i can say is i cant wait to see it again.The greatest thing about the movie is the acting.I think that most of the actors knew that they were appearing in a film that had its tongue placed firmly in its cheek.Max von Sydow gives a performance that is absolutely perfect ,one of the greatest screen villains of all time!Also giving a deliciously evil performance is Patrick Wyngarde as Klytus,the man in the mask.This movie has often been described as "camp"I disagree because in my opinion not everyone who uses that word has a clue as to what it actually means.Topol and Brian Blessed ham it up blissfully , and while Sam J Jones , Melody Anderson and Timothy Dalton dont play it for laughs they all give good performances despite what some people say.The special effects have been criticised on these pages but for 1980 i think the effects look o.k.Especially good are the effects involving the clouds on the planet Mongo.Look out for the famous English author and playwright John Osborne in a cameo.Great acting ,effects,score,pace,excitement, atmosphere and also the best entrance of a villain in any film anywhere!
It's a pity that this isn't shown on TV or any streaming services like Netflix etc. That would give many more people the opportunity to see it and enjoy it as well.

Review title: Wooden acting, laughable effects and a predictable plot
Review_body: As a kid I loved this film but I recently picked up the DVD and sat down to relive all those happy childhood memories. What a mistake that was! The plot has Ming threatening to destroy the earth via numerous weather induced catastrophes and eventually making the moon crash into the earth. Flash and Dale crash land in a plane at the lab of Dr Hans Zharkov and crawl from the wreckage without even a bruise. They are greeted by Hans Zharkov who asks if they are hurt and I suspect you want to use the telephone. Come on, like after a plane crash you wouldn't be hurt, in shock, worried about the plane blowing up and want to get away from it etc.The phone booth is really Hans Zharkov's rocket which he plans to use to launch a counterattack to save the earth. He plans to do this armed with a 6 shooter and no extra ammo. At least give him some decent guns and a few marines or something who could get killed later.They blast off fly through a ropey painting of some red sky which is spun around to give it some depth, land and are captured. They are taken to Mings palace which looks like a carnival in Rio. Flash spots Princess Aura in Mings palace and Dale who he met for the first time on the plane and has spoken a few words to suddenly berates him for looking at another woman. Sorry love but shes better looking and Flash isn't your property! Flash fights the guards in a mildly enjoyable football fight and is then sentenced to death. He is rescued by Princess Aura (who uses a doctor who she is knocking off to give him an injection) and taken to Arboria to the Barron who is supposed to be Auras lover (like you would take someone you fancy who's been saved by another one of your lovers round to your boyfriends kingdom - they must all be swingers on Mungo!) Barron plots to kill Flash despite saving him from a rubber beast and they are both taken to Vultans sky city. Barron and Flash fight, Flash saves his life and all of a sudden they are best mates. Mings secret policeman (dressed in black and wearing a mask Darth Vader anyone) turns up and Barron and Flash kill him. Vultan has to flee before his kingdom is blasted to atoms but is still happy to hear that Flash survived and helps him to attack Mings rocket Ajax.Why does the commander of War rocket Ajax stop all engines when attacked by the hawk-men. Basic military strategy would say use your speed to distance yourself and blast them or fly back to Mings and get some reinforcements but then that wouldn't help the film. A battle follows which is about as exciting as watching grass grow.Flash takes over the rocket and goes to fly it into Mings palace as there are only 3 and a bit minutes until the moon crashes into the earth. Flash crashes the rocket into Mings city manages to pierce Ming with the spike on the cone of the ship but not hurt himself and hence saves the day.Why does Mings death just seconds before the moon crashes into the earth suddenly stop the moon from crashing into the earth? Answer it wouldn't. Why is Ming getting married when the moon is about to destroy the earth - wouldn't he watch that first and then get married? Basically this is an awful film if you are over 10 years old, rubbish acting, terrible effects, and a plot with too many holes in it. If you are under 10, like amateur dramatics and like to watch bad films to see just how bad they are then watch this otherwise don't bother. The one saving grace is the music by Queen buy the soundtrack instead of the DVD!

Flash Gordon (1980) staring, Sam J. Jones as Flash Gordon, and Melody Anderson as the beautiful Dale Arden, is a remake or updated version of the 1930's comic strip Flash Gordon. The film starts out flashing filmed images of a man-made scientific piece of equipment designed to create catastrophic events like Hurricanes, Tornados and Floods. The theme of the movie is focused on saving Earth, from being destroyed, but we are initially led to believe it is from a mad scientist known as Dr. Hans Zarkov played by Topol. Zarkov is viewed as threat by the terrible Emperor Ming ( Max Von Skydow) who lives on another planet in the galaxy. Ming skyjacks the air bus that Flash and Dale are operating, along with capturing them in the accompaniment of Zarkov and here is where the film takes on its major animation.While still focusing on saving Earth, now from Enperor Ming, Zarkov, befriends Flash and together they set in motion the idea of saving the planet Earth from his plan of destruction. Emperor Ming views Dr. Zarkov as a threat to his kingdom, and wants his memory wiped clean back to his birth, but he manages to manipulate the process to keep his own thoughts safeguarded. This is your typical hero type of movie that saves the day, where Flash Gordon is the hero, originated from a comic strip just as Superman or Spiderman are turned into superhuman form in film, so is Flash Gordon. Maintaining the theme it becomes a battle of who will rule the galaxy, as the beings from Emperor Mings galaxy begin to lose ground against the three humans who eventually gain the trust of some of Ming's own people. Ming's galaxy is still divided by the different class of citizens, like the winged citizens, versus the others. Each battles for their own identity within the kingdom to begin with, and now you throw humans into the mix. None are quick to take sides with the humans to overthrow the terrible Emperor Ming but in the end, this is exactly what happens. Earth is saved from Ming's destruction, and Ming's kingdom is turned over to his daughter and her husband, after the destruction of Emperor Ming. The hero is none other than Flash Gordon, as is emphasized in the end, with a human gesture of saying Thanks. The hero saves the day, galaxy and Earth. Not bad for a days work!

The plot to Flash Gordon is very simple, "kill the bad guy, save the world and get the girl." The hero of the story is Mr. Flash Gordon himself played by Sam Jones. The "girl" is Ms. Dale Arden played by Melody Andersen. The most notable of other characters are the evil Emperor Ming played by Max Von Sydow and Dr. Hans Zarkov played by Topol.The focus of Flash Gordon is definitely on plot. I found it difficult to come to this conclusion because this film could have easily been a focus on character. It is not, though, because there is very little character development. The overall theme to this movie is teamwork and standing up to oppression. And who better to lead a movie toward teamwork than a main character who is a New York Jets star quarterback?The races of Mongo, the planet ruled by Emperor Ming, are always in conflict. This is merely to please the Emperor as he states in the film. While it is true that these races both hate and despise each other they also dislike the Emperor just as much, if not more. Enter Flash Gordon. Through his encounters with the major races, the Arboreans and Hawkmen, Flash manages to make them stop fighting each other.Just like in Lord of the Rings: Return of the King, the Arboreans and Hawkmen band together with Flash against their common enemy. Other parallels I see are that the Arboreans closely resemble the elves and the Hawkmen closely resemble the giant eagles of Lord of the Rings. The most impressive part of this film is where the Hawkmen descend upon an enemy rocket-ship to an epic rock ballad.The best thing about this film is the music. I must state that the music of the film and the actual sounds and effects are two very different elements. The music, done by Queen, greatly adds to the emotional impact and atmosphere of the scenes. The sounds and effects are unfortunately repetitive and artificial.The amazingly colorful backgrounds and overall use of colors in this film are also noteworthy. The backgrounds are like liquid paintings; pools of color jumping right off of the screen. The costumes of the different races of Mongo are both colorful and extravagant. These elements help to suggest to the viewer that Flash is really in some fantastic world trying to save our own.The absolute embodiment of the theme of teamwork is apparent in the final scenes of Flash Gordon. The collective races of Mongo are gathered on a balcony cheering and thanking Flash Gordon for saving them from the Emperor. Flash has killed the bad guy, saved the world, and gotten the girl.
Totally camp, totally comic, totally top tunes.  Don't bother analysing it, watch it, feel good.Dive my brave hawkmen.........................

Review title: The Best Worst Film Ever Made
Review_body: "The Godfather" is one of the undisputed greatest films of all time. The acting, the script, the direction, the way Clemenza drops those sausages in the sauce, the climatic baptism/blood bath -- everything about it is brilliant. Undisputed. Now, imagine everything in a film is made to be bad -- sets, costumes, acting, lines ... Campy, 6-year-old imagination bad. That's "Flash Gordon" ... the greatest bad movie of all time. It's as brilliant, and as a religious a cinematic experience as watching "Godfather." I just saw this gem again last week on DVD, and Lord, it's spectacular. Sam Jones is as bad an actor as Al Pacino is good. But, he's brilliant here, because Flash is supposed to be a clueless hero -- a football star tossed into a sci-fi intergalactic war that he can barely comprehend. He has his name written on his shirt for crying out loud. "FLASH" in big red letters against a white T-shirt. As if he'd forget his name if he didn't look down to his chest. And darn if Sam Jones doesn't look like he hasn't a clue what the heck is going on. Max Von Sydow is the evil Ming the Merciless. Dig the name. Dig his outfit. Dig that performance, he's an evil Christ with the mind of a 12-year-old who just discovered girls and morality. Add in Topol "If I Were a Rich Man" and Grade-Z Margot Kidder clone Melody Anderson as the girlfriend-babe Dale Arden, and ... oh, it's brilliant. Queen provides the over the top music score, singing of Flash as a Christ-like Savior of the Universe. Fred Mercury was a god, wasn't he? The film works on several levels. It's what every child imagines a comic book to look like if it were brought to life. Adults can have fun, too. It's a damn fine satire of law and marriage and live for adults, and religion and Communism and ..oh, just have fun. Some folks here say turn your brain off and enjoy. No! Turn your brain on and enjoy! Flash Gordon is a dream for heterosexuals, homosexuals .. the sexual references are endless. (The seduction-telepathic "phone call" scene is funnier and more out-there than anything I've sever seen. Tim Dalton's character protests against Flash ... a bit too much, maybe) Ming is impaled on a phallic-like rocket tip. The mythology is deep -- Robin Hood, Greek gods, etc, etc. It's trash, wonderful goofy, trash and I love every frame. For every kid who collected comic books, it's heaven. For every adult who wished he still collected comic books, it's heaven. Go ahead, watch the "Godfather." I love it, it's brilliant. But it ain't fun. This is fun. This is Saturday-afternoon cinema at it's best, and it has the gumption to proudly be what "Star Wars" couldn't help but become ... junk. Wonderful, beautiful, enjoyable junk. I love this film. There hasn't been a finer comic book movie then or since.

Review title: This is one 80's flick that does NOT need a remake!
Review_body: The plot of this movie plays out as if you asked a 1979 George Lucas to write down a sequel to Star Wars, but handed him the suitcase of drugs from "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas" in addition to a pen. Full of ludicrously awesome moments (such as Flash griping the command chair of a ship surrounded by burning controls as Queen chants "King of THE IMPOSSIBLE!!!"). William Bushey's review perfectly surmises the music as "Permanently freezing the movie in 1980", with Queen's amazing soundtrack delivering perfect exclamation marks to scenes. You definitely want your speakers turned up for this film. Although the rear-screen projection effects look dated in some scenes, the special effects have held up well enough for 33 years, with the laser effects looking crisp and bright, scenes filmed with miniatures seem to help ground the movie in it's comic book origins, as does the opening credits featuring the original comic. This 1980 classic not only captures the spirit of the original, but is filled with the perfect amount of campy moments that firmly ground the movie in the 1980s, much to the film's benefit. Any remake will not do this film justice. A remake may be a good film in its own right, but will never capture the 1980s energy that fills this movie to the brim. Without Queen's soundtrack to back it up, or the miniatures to help ground it in the comic I highly doubt a modern remake (which will eventually be made) will be able to capture the tone of this film.

Review title: A 1930's Comic Strip Brought Perfectly To Life
Review_body: Flash Gordon is one of the most perfectly realized films De Laurentiis made, and it is disappointing that so few have recognized it for what it is; a 1930's comic strip brought perfectly to life. The fact that it is so accurate a realization of America's hopes and fears during the 1930's may help to explain why it has been dismissed so readily as, at best, mere camp, and at worst, a vulgar cinematic catastrophe: Today's audiences are too removed from that decade to catch the references. A classic example of America's view of Asia during the 1930's can be found in Dale Arden's confrontation with Princess Aura just prior to her wedding to Ming. Aura is trying to convince Dale to slip a poison into Ming's "Power Potion" but Dale tells Aura she can't because she's given Ming her word to "try to be a good wife if [Ming] would spare Zarkov and Baron. He vowed he would." Aura, shocked at her naiveté, shouts, "My father has never kept a vow in his life!" To which Dale responds, "I can't help that Aura. Keeping our word is one of the things that make us better than you." Flash Gordon is filled with this type of wonderful 1930's fun, and this fun is only enhanced by the decision to use bad actors in roles that would only benefit from the lack of skill, as well as Oscar-caliber actors in the most demanding roles. Max Von Sydow is an obvious example of the latter, but the hidden gems come in the form of Mariangela Melato, Brian Blessed, and Ornella Muti. Melato does an outstanding job as Klytus's reptilian, but beautiful, second in command when she flawlessly delivers lines like, "Confess, and we won't hurt you anymore.We don't like doing this at all!" And Ornella Muti is simply unbelievable as Ming's gorgeous but deadly daughter. Replying to Flash's query as to whether he can use the telepathy machine to contact Dale with a perfectly candid, "If I showed you how. But I'm not going to." Add to these amazing actors the costumes and sets that are obvious homages to the original comic's drawings and you have a movie that is as surprising as it is delightful. Enjoy!

Flash Gordon resembles a zealous fitness fanatic as he traverses space dressed in lycra and using what appears to be some sort of treadmill as his main form of transportation. Review title: The most fun movie to watch...
Review_body: I loved this movie, when I saw it as a Saturday afternoon flik(1996). I have been looking for a copy (vhs/dvd) ever since. I admit that its a little cheezy, at first I dindnt now what it was and started channel flipping. Then I saw it or rather heard it "the names Flash 'Flash Gordon' my friends call me Flash..." I had heard this name all my life, being born in 1976 I was only 4 when it came out in theaters (1980). When I heard his name, something flashed in my mind "This is the Greatest Si-Fi ever created!" I had to see this. I have been inspired as an artist and writer ever since. anyone who doesn't like this film is a coward in heart. The special effects might have been lame, but the heart of the story is that "Flash Gordon" is a hero, and lets face it; "We all wish we could be hero's...but are we?"

Review title: Cheesy but actioned packed movie that is great for all viewers!
Review_body: The plot is taken right out of a comic book; hero rescues damsel in distress. To some this may give it away right there but performances from Topol, Max Von Syndow and Brian Best bring together a classic story that children and adults have loved for 3/4's of a century. It is well mixed with action, comedy and drama. One downfall of the movie is that the production value can not compete with the sci-fi movies made today. I first watched this movie at 16. I started it alone and by the end of the movie my whole family was watching it. It can definitely can be classified as cheesy but this is a category that both good and bad movies can fall into. The original Star Wars movie is quite cheesy and so is the original Star Trek series but both are classics. This movie does not compare to them, but it shows the validity of good classic cheesy movies that the whole family can enjoy and this is what Flash Gordon is.

Ive probably watched this movie over a thousand times. Im now 43. Heres all u need to know- -Can A quarterback from the New York Jets save not just the earth but the galaxy from evil? If that isnt enough to make u watch the sountrack is by Queen. ABSOLUTE CLASSIC!!

Review title: A moving comic book, that will suck you into a 30s American sci-fi story
Review_body: People don't understand this movie. Flash Gordon started the idea of putting comic books into move - great performance (actors act like in a comic book), awesome Queen music, and great feeling of these old comic books found in your (grand)father's basement between his old stuff from childhood. This movie is fantastic in this way. It's like a space and time machine that puts you into an another dimension of classical comic book story about a hero who saves the universe and representing all the values of real, brave and honest man from the West. This is the kind of story that shows fantastic world of good vs evil, truth and justice, bravery and friendship. It ain't one of the postmodernist movies showing gray world without good and evil that can't be divided. It's a moving comic book with awesome music about FLASH - THE SAVIOUR OF UNIVERSE. Just let your imagination travel there with him!
A perfect adoaption of the comic, and you can't go wrong with Queen doing the theme song. Watching it after 40 years is still as enjoyable as the first time.
